channel.title: Singapore on zed tan
channel.description: Recent content in Singapore on zed tan

item.title: David Lynch's BLUE VELVET: Beaumont v.s. Booth
item.description: Lynch’s BLUE VELVET is a film that I’ve come back to countless times, either out of the onset of a mood for strange, dark stories or out of sheer necessity (I’ve been taught this film/ have had to teach this film several times over the past few years). And each time, at each viewing, I always stop at the scene where Jeffrey Beaumont (MacLachlan) — such a child his character was — trapped in a car-ful of thugs telling Frank Booth (Hopper) to leave Dorothy Vallens (Rossellini) alone, to stop hitting her.

item.title: Zed Reads 002
item.description: This week: A quick peek at the ethics of Michale Haneke’s films, Žižek on the instability of nature, geeking out on a nifty hardware prototyping kit, and on Instagram and the inadequacy of current attitudes towards Intellectual Property. Michael Haneke’s Cinema: The Ethic of the Image. “Introduction” | Catherine Wheatley. Berghahn Books, 2009 Wheatley’s book on Michael Haneke’s powerfully (emotionally) violent films has been on my to-read list for the longest time.
